subject: Re: [junit] Re: junit tests and functional/ integration tests
msgSnippet: ... I guess I don t always write a test per class.  If a few classes are intended to be used together, I ll write a test communicating that intent and forego
messageBody:
Ray Tayek wrote:

>
> > The acceptance tests don't use the unit or
> >integration tests. The integration tests don't use the unit tests. Each
> >type of
> >test is intended for different types of feedback at different frequencies.
>
> this is good to know.
>
> >Could you give an example?
>
> i guess i am thinking about a hierarchy:
>
> unit (class) test for each class in a package
> package test (can the classes in the package work together).
> go up to the parent package and rinse til done.
>

I guess I don't always write a test per class. If a few classes are intended to be
used together, I'll write a test communicating that intent and forego class-level
tests. Often times I'll write a test for each class, as well. It's a judgment
call. Regardless, the tests are independent and can be run in any order.


>
> the cactus testing is very dependent on many things. so id httpunit
> testing, and i had not thought in terms of acceptance testing. also, unit
> test of a web app seems very far away from the unit test of a class.
>

Each of these types of tests view the software from a different perspective. A
test from one perspective shouldn't be dependent on a test from another. I might
run a unit test every 5 minutes, an integration test every hour, and an acceptance
test once per day.

Does that help?

Mike
